title: Analysis of Functions - Graphs of f and f prime

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graphs of the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its derivative <math alttext="f prime"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For how many values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> does the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> equal the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over that interval?

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. The graphs of the function <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and its derivative <math alttext="f prime"><mrow><msup><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></math> are shown above for <math alttext="negative 1 less than or equal to x, less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Find the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. For how many values of <math alttext="x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> in the interval <math alttext="negative 1 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to 4"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> does the instantaneous rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> equal the average rate of change of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> over that interval?

(b) Write an equation for the line tangent to the graph of <math alttext="f"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="x equals 1"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) For each of <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 2, of, the fraction with numerator f of x, minus, f of 2, and denominator x minus 2, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the limit as x approaches 3, of, the fraction with numerator f of x, minus, f of 3, and denominator x minus 3, end fraction"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></munder><mfrac><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, find the value or give a reason why it does not exist.

(d) Let <math alttext="g"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="g of x, equals, e to the x power, times, f of x"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="g prime of 0"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

topic.text: 2.1: Defining Average and Instantaneous Rates of Change at a Point

skill.text: Skill 2.B: Identify mathematical information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and/or verbal representations.
